title: When I sing, my Adam's Apple is always moving up and down relative to pitch, how do you sing with your diaphragm instead of your throat? - Quora

response.answer_text: Several things come into play in singing properly & comfortably. Keeping the jaw/neck, shoulders “relaxed”, tension is a Killer to the cords, it constricts them, making singing far more difficult, plus it can cause damage.Taking the proper breath(s) ( closed mouth, Breathing through ones’ nose, Quietly, not a “Sniffy” breath, & w/Shoulders Down/relaxed, shoulders should Not move Up when taking a breath/breathing),tongue positioning, mouth position… Watch yourself in a mirror, standing relaxed, w/lips together, teeth apart, tongue relaxed,the rib cage should “expand Putwardly, Not Up & Down”, Support your breath/notes from Deep Down… You should feel like you’re doing “abdominal crunches”….Another little trick, is to “pretend you’re holding a Frozen Pea between your butt cheeks”( laugh as you may, it Does Work! )….

OK. Please listen carefully: You cannot sing with your diaphragm. It is a physical impossibility. All vocal sounds are generated in your larynx which happen to be in your throat. The only function of the diaphragm is to regulate air flow from the lungs. That’s it. Now about the moving Adam’s apple. It’s supposed to do that. As you sing higher pitches, the larynx will rise in the vocal tract and slide downward as you produce low pitches. It’s just the way your voice works. I’m sorry to sound so abrupt, but this type of question keeps appearing. It is astounding the amount of misinformation about the process of vocalization that exists.
